articles.headline: At Least 200 Feared Dead in Apartments Hit by Russia, Officials Say
articles.snippet: After Russian forces withdrew from Borodyanka, a commuter town near Ukraine’s capital, families are searching the rubble for bodies.
articles.abstract: After Russian forces withdrew from Borodyanka, a commuter town near Ukraine’s capital, families are searching the rubble for bodies.
articles.lead_paragraph: BORODYANKA, Ukraine — Andreiy Ziuzko stood near the flattened apartment complex in Borodyanka that was once his home, his belongings in plastic bags on the sidewalk beside a few blackened cooking pots on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

articles.headline: Zelensky Accuses Russia of Atrocities and Criticizes U.N.’s Inaction
articles.snippet: In a blistering address to the United Nations Security Council, Ukraine’s president asked what use the body was if it would not intervene to stop a war of aggression.
articles.abstract: In a blistering address to the United Nations Security Council, Ukraine’s president asked what use the body was if it would not intervene to stop a war of aggression.
articles.lead_paragraph: With evidence mounting of atrocities in the Kyiv suburbs, and Russian forces preparing for a new offensive farther east, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivered a scathing speech to the United Nations on Tuesday, accusing Russia of a litany of horrors and questioning whether a world body that takes no action to stop a war serves any purpose.

articles.headline: Abortion Pills, Once a Workaround, Are Now a Target
articles.snippet: In advance of a Supreme Court decision, states are proposing new restrictions and heavier criminal penalties on medication abortion.
articles.abstract: In advance of a Supreme Court decision, states are proposing new restrictions and heavier criminal penalties on medication abortion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, after Texas passed its strict abortion ban, surgical abortions in the state dropped by half. Many women found a workaround: pills. The week the law took effect, requests for medication abortion shot up to 138 a day from 11 a day at just one service that delivers the pills by mail.

articles.headline: Why Tracking Putin’s Wealth Is So Difficult
articles.snippet: Amid speculation that oligarchs are holding cash and luxury assets for the Russian president, many of his extravagances can be traced elsewhere: the Russian state.
articles.abstract: Amid speculation that oligarchs are holding cash and luxury assets for the Russian president, many of his extravagances can be traced elsewhere: the Russian state.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buried in a 421-page legal filing in an obscure court case is a single sentence, offered almost as an afterthought, about a meeting at a Geneva restaurant where two businessmen chatted about “a yacht which had been presented to Mr. Putin.”

articles.headline: The End of the (Pipe)line? Germany Scrambles to Wean Itself Off Russian Gas
articles.snippet: Dangerously dependent on Russian gas, Germany is still refusing to cut off President Putin, whose war it is effectively subsidizing to the tune of some $220 million a day.
articles.abstract: Dangerously dependent on Russian gas, Germany is still refusing to cut off President Putin, whose war it is effectively subsidizing to the tune of some $220 million a day.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUBMIN, Germany — Past a nudist beach and a sleepy marina, a gigantic mesh of metallic pipes rises from the pine forest behind the tiny village of Lubmin on Germany’s Baltic coast.

articles.headline: You’re Still Being Tracked on the Internet, Just in a Different Way
articles.snippet: Apple and Google are pushing privacy changes, but a shift in digital tracking is giving some platforms a bigger advertising advantage.
articles.abstract: Apple and Google are pushing privacy changes, but a shift in digital tracking is giving some platforms a bigger advertising advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: The internet industry shuddered last year when Apple introduced privacy measures for the iPhone that threatened to upend online tracking and cripple digital advertising. Google pledged similar privacy actions.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: With a $2.1 Million Cure Their Only Hope, Parents Plead for Help Online
articles.snippet: India makes many of the world’s drugs, but treatments for rare diseases like spinal muscular atrophy are imported and prohibitively costly. In desperation, parents are raising funds on social media.
articles.abstract: India makes many of the world’s drugs, but treatments for rare diseases like spinal muscular atrophy are imported and prohibitively costly. In desperation, parents are raising funds on social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELURU, India — When her baby started struggling to breathe, Stella Praveen had a terrible feeling that something was gravely wrong with her 14-month-old daughter, Ellen.
articles.byline: By Sameer Yasir, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Sara Hylton

articles.headline: Meet DALL-E, the A.I. That Draws Anything at Your Command
articles.snippet: New technology that blends language and images could serve graphic artists — and speed disinformation campaigns.
articles.abstract: New technology that blends language and images could serve graphic artists — and speed disinformation campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At OpenAI, one of the world’s most ambitious artificial intelligence labs, researchers are building technology that lets you create digital images simply by describing what you want to see.

articles.headline: Traces of Lives Cut Short: Bread on a Park Bench, Blood Pooled Nearby
articles.snippet: The violence of war is often random. Those who suffer most are the civilians caught in the middle. Two recent deaths in Kharkiv, Ukraine, are a testament to that.
articles.abstract: The violence of war is often random. Those who suffer most are the civilians caught in the middle. Two recent deaths in Kharkiv, Ukraine, are a testament to that.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — A loaf of bread on a park bench, collecting snow. A puddle of blood nearby.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

articles.headline: The Growing Religious Fervor in the American Right: ‘This Is a Jesus Movement’
articles.snippet: Rituals of Christian worship have become embedded in conservative rallies, as praise music and prayer blend with political anger over vaccines and the 2020 election.
articles.abstract: Rituals of Christian worship have become embedded in conservative rallies, as praise music and prayer blend with political anger over vaccines and the 2020 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
